intro: Venidium semipapposum, commonly known as the narrowleaf venidium, is a herbaceous plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, white to pale yellow flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the family. Its fruits are small, dry, and have a pappus, which aids in wind dispersal. Venidium semipapposum is often found in rocky soils and dry habitats, showing adaptability to arid environments.
